revised_title: Peripheral and Central Changes in Nerve Supply to Whiskers: Regeneration and Functional Impacts
tldr: The study investigates the effects of cutting or crushing the afferent nerve supply to whiskers in rats. Both procedures result in nerve regeneration, but cut lesions show less successful axon regeneration and a slower recovery rate. The research also examines the functional changes in the somatosensory cortex and trigeminal nucleus, showing that nerve-cut animals have more significant abnormalities and a longer recovery time compared to nerve-crushed animals.
